First, proximate causes, and second, distant causes.
The proximate is the purity of body, speech, and mind;
The distant is prolonging one's years and benefiting one's life.
This is called the remaining effect.
The equal effect refers to the vessel of the world.
Such effects also have two kinds of causes:

As for the result of retribution, it is like when a person obtains a pure body and cultivates pure actions of body, speech, and mind. This person will say:

Such a result has two kinds of causes:

The result of separation refers to nirvana, which is free from all afflictions.

In worldly dharmas, sometimes the generative cause is spoken of, and sometimes the revealing cause is spoken of;
The Dharma of transcendence is also like this, speaking of the cause of birth and the cause of realization.

Good man!
Far from afflictions, one can clearly see nirvana. Therefore, nirvana only has the cause of realization and not the cause of birth.
Good man!

Because the arhat permanently severs the causes and conditions of birth in the three times, he therefore says of himself 'my births are exhausted';
He also severs the five aggregates of the body in the three realms, and therefore he also says 'my births are exhausted';
Because the holy life he cultivated has been perfected, he therefore proclaims 'the holy life has been established';

one should know that such a person slanders the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.

'All sentient beings are completely devoid of buddha-nature, just like rabbit horns. It arises from skillful means, not existing before but existing now, and existing again later.'
You should know that such a person slanders the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.

'The buddha-nature of sentient beings is not existent, like space;
It is not nonexistent, like a rabbit's horns.
Why is this?

Because space is permanent and rabbit horns are nonexistent, therefore it can be said to be both existent and nonexistent. Because of existence, rabbit horns are refuted; because of nonexistence, space is refuted.'
One who speaks like this does not slander the Three Jewels.
Good son!
Buddha-nature is not called one dharma, not called ten dharmas, not called a hundred dharmas, not called a thousand dharmas, not called ten thousand dharmas.
Before attaining supreme, perfect enlightenment, all good, bad, and neutral [actions] are called buddha-nature.
The TathÄgata sometimes speaks of the effect in terms of the cause, and the cause in terms of the effect. This is called the TathÄgata's speech according to his own intention.
Because of speaking according to his own intention, he is called the TathÄgata;
because of speaking according to his own intention, he is called the Arhat;
because of speaking according to his own intention, he is called the Samyak-saá¹ƒbuddha.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa said:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, the Buddha-nature of sentient beings is like empty space.
What is meant by being like empty space?
Good man!
The nature of empty space is neither past, nor future, nor present;
the Buddha-nature is also like this.
Good man!
Empty space is not past.
Why is it so?
Because there is no present.
If a dharma is present, one can speak of the past;
because there is no present, there is no past.
There is also no present.
Why is it so?

There is also no future.

The absence of things is precisely space;
The buddha-nature is also like this.
Good son!
Because space does not exist, it is not included in the three times;
Because the buddha-nature is permanent, it is not included in the three times.
Good son!
The TathÄgata has already attained supreme perfect enlightenment, and the Buddha-nature and all Buddha-dharmas are permanent and unchanging.
For this reason, there is no three times, just like space.
Good son!
Because space does not exist, it is neither internal nor external;
Because the Buddha-nature is permanent, it is neither internal nor external.
Therefore, it is said that the Buddha-nature is like space.
Good son!
In the world, a place without obstruction is called space.

For this reason, I say that the Buddha-nature is like space.
Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

Being apart from such insentient objects is called buddha-nature.
Good man!
In all worlds, there is nothing that is not space in contrast to space.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

Space is without opposition, why can it not be called existent?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If it is said:

Good man!
It is like worldly people saying that space is called formless, unimpeded, and invisible.

If it is included in the three times, then it is the four aggregates.

The non-Buddhists say:

Because it is impermanent, it is included in the three times.
How can the non-Buddhists say it is not in the three times?
If it is included in the three times, then it is not space. It can also be said that space is permanent.'
Good man!
Some people say that space is precisely a dwelling place.
If there is a place, it is a form, and all places are impermanent, included in the three times. Space is also permanent and not included in the three times.
If one speaks of a place, one knows there is no space.
There are also those who say that space is sequence.
If it is sequence, it is a counted dharma;
if it is countable, it is included in the three times;
if it is included in the three times, how can it be said to be permanent?
Good man!
If one further says:
'Space is not apart from three dharmas:
First, empty, second, real, third, empty and real.
' If one says that emptiness is it, one should know that space is an impermanent dharma.
Why is it so?
Because the place of reality does not exist.
If one says that reality is it, one should know that space is also impermanent.
Why is it so?
Because the place of emptiness does not exist.
If one says that emptiness and reality are it, one should know that space is also impermanent.
Why is it so?
Because there are no two places.
Therefore, space is called non-existent.
Good son!

If it is said that space is a created dharma, it is said that by removing trees and houses, space is created, space is leveled, space covers space, and the color of space is painted above space, like the water of the great ocean.
Therefore, space is a created dharma.
All created dharmas are impermanent, like a clay pot;
if space is like this, it should be impermanent.
Good son!
If worldly people say that the unobstructed place among all dharmas is called space, is this unobstructed place completely existent in one dharma?
Or is it partially existent?
If it is completely existent, one should know that other places have no space.
If it is partially existent, it is a countable dharma that can be distinguished;
if it is countable, one should know it is impermanent.
Good son!
If someone says:
'Space is unobstructed and combines with existence,'
And further says:
'Space is in things, like fruit in a container,'
Both are unreasonable.
Why is it so?
If it is said to combine, there are three kinds:
1. Combination of different karmas, like flying birds gathering on a tree;
2. Combination of shared karmas, like two rams butting against each other;
3. Combination of already combined, like two pairs of fingers combining in one place.
If it is said to be a combination of different karmas, different means two:
1. The karma of things, 2. The karma of space.
If the karma of space combines with things, space is impermanent;
If the karma of things combines with space, things are not all-pervading. If they are not all-pervading, they are also impermanent.
If it is said:
'Space is permanent, its nature is unmoving, and it combines with moving things,'
This is unreasonable.
Why is it so?
If space is permanent, objects should also be permanent;
if objects are impermanent, space should also be impermanent.
If it is said that space is both permanent and impermanent, this is not possible.
If it is said that space is combined with karma, this is not reasonable.
Why is this?
Space is said to be all-pervading. If it is combined with karma, karma should also be all-pervading;
if it is all-pervading, it should pervade everything;
if it pervades everything, it should be combined with everything, and it should not be said that there is combination and non-combination.
If it is said:
'Already combined and combined together, like two pairs of fingers combined,'
this is unreasonable.
Why is this?
Because there was no combination before, and it is combined later.
What did not exist before and exists later is an impermanent dharma. Therefore, it cannot be said that space is already combined and combined together.
Just as worldly dharmas did not exist before and exist later, these objects are impermanent;
if space is also like this, it should also be impermanent.
If it is said:
'Space is in things, like fruit in a vessel.'
This is not so.
Why is it so?
If space, before there are vessels, is in what place does it abide?
If there is an abiding place, space would then be multiple.
If it is multiple, how can it be said to be permanent?
How can it be said to be one?
How can it be said to be all-pervading?
If space abides apart from emptiness, then things should also abide apart from space. Therefore, one should know that there is no space.
Good son!
If someone says that the place where the finger abides is called space, one should know that space is an impermanent dharma.
Why is it so?
The finger has four sides.
If it has four sides, one should know that space also has four sides.
All permanent dharmas have no direction. Because it has direction, space is impermanent.
If it is impermanent, it is not apart from the five skandhas. One must be apart from the five skandhas, and then it is non-existent.
Good son!
If a dharma abides due to causes and conditions, know that this dharma is called impermanent.
Good son!
It is like all sentient beings and trees and plants that abide due to the earth. Because the earth is impermanent, the things that depend on the earth are also impermanent.
Good son!
It is like the earth depending on water. Because water is impermanent, the earth is also impermanent.
It is like water depending on wind. Because wind is impermanent, water is also impermanent.
Wind depends on space. Because space is impermanent, wind is also impermanent.
If it is impermanent, how can it be said that space is permanent and pervades everywhere?
Because space does not exist, it is not past, future, or present;
It is also like a rabbit's horns, because they are non-existent, they are not past, future, or present.
Therefore, I say that because buddha-nature is permanent, it is not included in the three times;
Because space does not exist, it is not included in the three times.
Good son!
I will never argue with the world.
Why is it so?
When worldly wisdom speaks of existence, I also speak of existence;
when worldly wisdom speaks of non-existence, I also speak of non-existence.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa said:
World-Honored One!
How many dharmas are possessed by Bodhisattva-Mahasattvas that they do not argue with the world and are not defiled by worldly dharmas?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Bodhisattva-Mahasattvas who possess ten dharmas do not argue with the world and are not defiled by worldly dharmas.
What are the ten?

First, having faith; second, having precepts; third, being close to good friends; fourth, good thoughts within; fifth, being replete with vigor; sixth, being replete with right mindfulness; seventh, being replete with wisdom; eighth, being replete with right speech; ninth, delighting in the right Dharma; tenth, having compassion for sentient beings.

Bodhisattvas who are endowed with these ten dharmas do not dispute with the world, and are not defiled by worldly dharmas, like an utpala flower.
KÄÅ›yapa Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said:
'When worldly wisdom speaks of existence, I also speak of existence;
when worldly wisdom speaks of non-existence, I also speak of non-existence.'
What is meant by worldly wisdom speaking of existence and non-existence?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If worldly wisdom speaks of form as impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self, and so on up to consciousness,
good man!
This is called worldly wisdom speaking of existence, and I also speak of existence.
Good man!
If worldly wisdom speaks of form as lacking permanence, bliss, self, and purity, and so on up to feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness,
good man!

KÄÅ›yapa Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
The wise ones in the world are the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and all sages.
If the sages say that form is impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self, why does the Thus-Come One say that the Buddha's form body is permanent, constant, and unchanging?
How can the Thus-Come One say that what the wise ones in the world say does not exist is actually existent?

The Thus-Come One has already departed from the three kinds of inversions, namely the inversion of thought, the inversion of mind, and the inversion of views. He should say that the Buddha's form is truly impermanent, yet now he says it is permanent. How can he be said to be far removed from inversion and not dispute with the world?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The form of ordinary beings arises from afflictions, therefore the wise say that form is impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self;

World-Honored One!
How is it that form arises from afflictions?

Knowing the faults, one can then distance oneself from them.

The blind person will find it extremely difficult to get out later, and even if they manage to get out, their body will be completely ruined.

Knowing the faults of offenses, even if one experiences the results of retribution, the results will be light.

There are four kinds of people:

2. Those whose actions are light when committed but heavy when experienced;

4. Those whose actions are light when committed and also light when experienced.

If a person is able to contemplate the faults of afflictions, then their actions and the results they experience will both be light.

A wise person thinks like this:
'I should stay far away from such defilements, and moreover, I should not commit such contemptible and evil deeds.
Why is this?
Because I have not yet escaped the retribution of hell, hungry ghosts, animals, humans, and gods.
If I cultivate the path, I will rely on this power to destroy all suffering.'
This person, having contemplated, has weakened greed, anger, and delusion.
Having seen greed, anger, and delusion to be light, his mind is joyful, and he further thinks like this:
'I am now like this, all due to the power of the causes and conditions of cultivating the path, causing me to be able to leave unwholesome dharmas and be close to wholesome dharmas.
Therefore, in the present I see the right path and should diligently cultivate it.'

If a person can know the afflictions, the causes of the afflictions, the retribution of the afflictions, the lightness and heaviness of the afflictions, and diligently cultivates the holy path in order to eliminate the afflictions, this person will not give rise to form from the afflictions. Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are also like this.

If one cannot know the afflictions, the causes of the afflictions, the retribution of the afflictions, the lightness and heaviness of the afflictions, and does not diligently cultivate [the path], this person will then give rise to form from the afflictions. Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are also like this.
Good man!

Knowing afflictions, the causes of afflictions, the fruits of retribution for afflictions, and the relative weight of afflictions, and cultivating the path to eliminate afflictions is precisely the TathÄgata.
For this reason, the form of the TathÄgata is permanent, and so are his consciousness and the rest.
Good man!

Not knowing afflictions, the causes of afflictions, the fruits of retribution for afflictions, and the relative weight of afflictions, and being unable to cultivate the path is precisely an ordinary person.
Therefore, the form of an ordinary person is impermanent, and so are his feelings, perceptions, mental formations, and consciousness.
Good man!
The wise ones in the world, all the sages, bodhisattvas, and buddhas expound these two meanings, and I also expound these two meanings in the same way.
Therefore, I say that I do not dispute with the wise ones in the world, and I am not defiled by worldly dharmas.

Ignorance is the root of all defilements.
Why is it so?

Because of the causes and conditions of ignorance, all sentient beings form concepts and names for the aggregates, sense bases, and elements, which is called sentient beings. This is called the inversion of thought, the inversion of mind, and the inversion of views.
Because of these causes and conditions, all defilements arise.
Therefore, I have said in the twelve divisions of the scriptures that ignorance is the cause of greed, the cause of anger, and the cause of delusion.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa said:
World-Honored One!
In the past, the Tathagata said in the twelve divisions of the scriptures that unwholesome thoughts cause greed, anger, and delusion to arise. Why does he now say it is due to ignorance?
Good man!

These two dharmas mutually become causes and conditions for each other, mutually increasing and growing. Unwholesome thoughts give rise to ignorance, and the causes and conditions of ignorance give rise to unwholesome thoughts.
Good man!
Those that can give rise to and increase the afflictions are all called causes and conditions of the afflictions;
Being close to such causes of afflictions is called ignorance and unwholesome thoughts.
Just as a seed produces a sprout, the seed is the proximate cause, and the four great elements are the distant cause;
Afflictions are also like this.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, ignorance is the same as the defilements.
How can it be said that because of ignorance, the defilements arise?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
As for the defilement of ignorance that I have spoken of, it is internal ignorance.
As for the arising of the defilements because of ignorance, it is both internal and external causes.
If one speaks of the defilement of ignorance, this is called internal delusion, not recognizing impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self;
If one speaks of the causes and conditions of all afflictions, this is called not knowing the self and what belongs to the self externally;
If one speaks of the defilement of ignorance, this is called having no beginning and no end, arising from ignorance, the aggregates, sense bases, elements, and so forth.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, a wise person knows the causes of defilements.
What is meant by knowing the causes of defilements?
Good man!

Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
How can a single sentient being give rise to various afflictions?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Just as there are various seeds in a single vessel, which grow individually upon receiving water and rain,
sentient beings are also like this. Although the vessel is one, due to the causes and conditions of craving, various afflictions can be produced and grow.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa said:
World-Honored One!
How do the wise contemplate karmic retributions?
Good man!
The wise should contemplate:
The causes and conditions of the various defilements can give rise to the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals;
The causes and conditions of these defilements result in the bodies of humans and gods, which are impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self;
Within this vessel of the body, three kinds of suffering and three kinds of impermanence are obtained;

These causes and conditions of defilements can cause sentient beings to commit the five heinous crimes, receive various evil retributions, sever their wholesome roots, violate the four grave prohibitions, and slander the Three Jewels.
The wise should contemplate:
Since I have already obtained such a body, I should not give rise to such afflictions and receive various evil fruits.

All sages truly have no outflows and karmic effects. All sages cultivate the path and the karmic effects are not born again, and therefore it is called the outflows and karmic effects.

When a wise person contemplates in this way, they will be able to eternally extinguish the karmic effects of afflictions.
